required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Medical Imaging Quantization in Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Optimization of 18F-choline PET/CT Acquisition in Prostate Cancer: Preliminary Results Concerning the Length of the Acquisition

brief_summary.textblock:
Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men over 50 years old and the third leading cause of cancer death. Because of the variety of prostate cancers, different treatments exist.
Several criteria guide this management in daily practice: PSA level; TNM stage (digital rectal examination, trans-rectal ultrasound and classical visual imaging) and pathological differentiation with the Gleason score, to which can be added other prognostic criteria: growth and doubling time of the serum PSA, number of positive biopsies and percentage of cancer lesions by biopsy.
Functional imaging by PET and MRI is increasingly used in daily clinical practice to characterize prostate cancer, either during initial discovery or during recurrence. In this context, it is the qualitative visual analysis that is mainly used. Quantitative image analysis could add new criteria to guide patient management.
Consequently, the objective of this study were:
- Optimization of 18F-choline PET/CT Acquisition in Prostate Cancer
- Comparison the quantitative parameters obtained by 18F-Choline PET / CT and both perfusion MRI and histological parameters.

primary_outcome.measure: correlation between Gleason score and dynamic parameters on PET and MRI
primary_outcome.time_frame: when anatomopathological report is available, an average of 3 months after the PET/CT
primary_outcome.description: study the potential correlation between dynamic parameters on PET and MRI

secondary_outcome.time_frame: when all 18F-choline PET are performed, an average of 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: determine the mean influx from each reconstruction which is the closest to the objective value

secondary_outcome.time_frame: when all MRI are performed, an average of 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: the Akaike Criteria Information was chose to choose the best fit

secondary_outcome.measure: comparison between data (PSA, TNM stage, EFS and OS)
secondary_outcome.description: comparison between data (PSA, TNM stage, EFS and OS)

study_pop.textblock: Patients with prostate cancer histologically proven included in Brest University Hospital between 01/07/2012 and 01/10/2015 and underwent F-choline PET/CT and pelvic MRI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients with prostate cancer histologically proven included in Brest University Hospital between 01/07/2012 and 01/10/2015 and underwent F-choline PET/CT and pelvic MRI Patient consent
Exclusion Criteria:
No lesion on dynamic acquisition on PET/CT and/or on pelvic MRI
